events.name: SPSS Data Analysis
events.description:
Introducing SPSS, creating a data file and data entry, descriptive analyses, reliability, normality, correlation, t-test, ANOVA analysis, regression, and non-parametric analyses with examples

At the end of this training, you will be able to do your own thesis.

Participants must install the SPSS program on their computers before the training.

events.name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy Program for Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder
events.description:
Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) is a heterogeneous psychiatric disorder characterized by individuals avoiding certain foods or food categories due to increased sensitivity to sensory characteristics (e.g., taste, texture, appearance, smell) of food and/or restricting intake in quantity. One of the most common reasons for avoidance and restriction in ARFID is increased sensitivity to sensory characteristics of food. Individuals diagnosed with ARFID may also avoid or restrict food due to fear of unwanted outcomes such as choking, vomiting, or gastrointestinal pain. These individuals often experience a trauma related to food and then begin to avoid certain foods to protect themselves from another adverse experience. Individuals with ARFID also often show a lack of interest in food or eating and may maintain a limited diet in terms of quantity. Those with lack of interest describe eating as a chore, and this is often reflected in a low appetite.

Psychological therapies are prominent in the treatment of ARFID. A cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT-AR) has been developed for ARFID. This therapy includes three optional modules that the therapist can apply depending on the patientâ€™s primary maintenance mechanism. This therapy can be applied in an individual format or with family support, depending on the patient's age, and can last 20-30 sessions depending on the severity of the eating disorder. This training will address ARFID treatment from a psychotherapeutic perspective.

This program consists of 4 sessions and a total of 8 hours.

events.name: Free Webinar: Safe Haven: Psychotherapy with Children and Adolescents
events.description:
Participation is open to everyone and a digital participation certificate will be shared with live viewers.

We are coming together on the evening of September 12, 2024, at 21.00 to talk about the 'safe haven'.

The safe haven is a concept developed by Dr. Darcia Narvaez that describes the necessary care system for babies, children, and adolescents to reach their potential. The safe haven aims to meet the emotional, social, and physiological needs of children with evolutionary proven care practices and environmental conditions.

How to create a safe haven? How can psychotherapy and psychoeducation be used to provide a safe haven for babies, children, and adolescents? How can psychotherapists, parents, and educators collaborate to support the healthy development of children?

Letâ€™s come together to grow and create a safe and supportive haven for our babies, children, and adolescents. Looking forward to seeing you on September 12 at 21:00.

How can we benefit from body-oriented work while working with couples? What are the body-oriented practices and techniques we can use to strengthen the couple's relationship?
